title: Request for Records on NYPD Mounted Unit Horses

communications.subject: New York Freedom of Information Law Request: Request for Records on NYPD Mounted Unit Horses
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the New York Freedom of Information Law, I hereby request the following records:

Any  and all records, including but not limited to emails, memos, physical documents, standing orders  and any other records, related to NYPD police horses from January 1st, 2020, to the present date.

Please provide the following information for each NYPD police horse during the aforementioned timeframe:

Name and badge number of the horse
Breed and sex of the horse
Dates of service for the horse
Any complaints or disciplinary actions against the horse or its handler(s)
Additionally, please provide any records related to court cases or legal proceedings involving NYPD police horses during the aforementioned timeframe.

Please note that the requested records do not hinder any police techniques or investigations. Also, please do not withhold, redact, or delete any responsive records, as I will take legal action to compel their disclosure, and will file a complaint with the appropriate authorities.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Jordan Lassiter

title: Anderson County Sheriff Department (Tenn.) investigation into library books

communications.subject: Tennessee Public Records Act Request: Anderson County Sheriff Department (Tenn.) investigation into library books
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Tennessee Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

1. Any letter, email, text message, or other correspondence concerning any complaint or investigation concerning the content of books, materials, or programs at any public library. . This includes, but is not limited to any correspondence sent to received from any County Commissioner, the County Law Director (or any Assistant Law Director), the District Attorney (or any Assistant District Attorney), and any complainant or witness to such an investigation.

2. The letter from Sheriff Barker to the County Commission (or its members) stating that: "Both books appear to have a political agenda that promotes a specific ideology related to gender and sexuality, which may be confusing or potentially harmful to young readers who are still developing their understanding of these concepts."

3. A copy of the March 29, 2023 opinion by Anderson County District Attorney General David Clark concerning library books.

4. Any complaints, incident reports, narrative reports, or other records relating to any complaint or investigation concerning the content of books, materials, or programs at any public library. 

5. Any records generated or received in connection with any investigation concerning the content of books, materials, or programs at any public library. This includes any records referenced in any complaint or incident report concerning such an investigation. These records may also include photographs, video, or body camera footage generated or received during the investigation.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 7 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Kent Hoover, a citizen of Tennessee, in coordination with Adam Steinbaugh.

title: FOIA - FBI - SST Records

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: FOIA - FBI - SST Records
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

All records mentioning and/or relating to SST Records - an American independent music record label formed in 1978 in Long Beach, California by musician Greg Ginn (see: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SST_Records).

Please conduct a thorough search of the Central Records System, including but not limited to the Electronic Surveillance (ELSUR) Indices, the Physical Surveillance (FISUR) Indices, the Microphone Surveillance (MISUR) Indices, and the Technical Surveillance (TESUR) Indices - for both main-file records and cross-reference records for all relevant names, individuals, agencies and companies. 

If any potentially responsive records have been destroyed and/or transferred to NARA, then I request copies of the destruction or transfer slips as well as any other documentation relating to, mentioning or describing said transfer or destruction, to include but not be limited to confirmation that the Bureau has no other copies of said records. If previously released records are available, then I request a rolling release consisting of those records while additional records are located and processed for release.

Please see the following news publication to serve as proof of death: https://www.tabletmag.com/sections/history/articles/the-purge-chandler-davis

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

J Ader

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: CCC 4.20.23
communications.communication:
Dear FOIA Officer:

You are receiving this correspondence as a request under the Freedom of Information Act, 5 U.S.C. subsection 552. I am requesting the following:

Copies of all Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) records, documents, and communications responsive to case file 94-HQ-50997, for the Campus Crusade for Christ, aka Cru. The group was founded by William R. Bright, aka Bill Bright (October 19, 1921 – July 19, 2003), as an evangelical ministry for college students in 1951. Some of the information in the case file is publicly available courtesy of writer Lerone A. Martin, who identifies communications between Campus Crusade leaders and former FBI director J. Edgar Hoover in his book "The Gospel of J. Edgar Hoover: How the FBI Aided and Abetted the Rise of White Christian Nationalism", published in April 2023, but the file itself has not been made public. This would be of public interest for two reasons:

First, it would contribute significantly to public understanding of the operations and activities of the government. Hoover, per Martin, used the Campus Crusade as a vehicle to promote his personal and professional interests. The Campus Crusade distributed Bureau materials and Hoover's writing appeared in a 1962 issue of a Campus Crusade publication, The Collegiate Challenge, in an article titled “Freedom Begins with Christ”. The Campus Crusade's file would provide the public with a clearer understanding of J. Edgar Hoover's relationship with faith leaders during his tenure as FBI director.

Second, during its existence, the Campus Crusade has maintained associations with known domestic terrorist organizations such as the Covenant, the Sword, the Arm and the Lord (CSA), an anti-government militia group and member of the Christian identity movement which bought farmland from the Campus Crusade in the early 1980s (please see: 100-HQ-487200). Per the FBI case file on the CSA, the Bureau launched a multi-year investigation into the group, culminating in a 1985 raid on the property the CSA purchased from the Campus Crusade. The Campus Crusade's interactions with domestic terrorist organizations make it a subject of public interest.

I am asking you waive any fees associated with this request. I am a member of the news media and request classification as such. My bylines, which include Creem Magazine, Covert Action Magazine, and the Geopolitical Economy Report, can be found in both print and electronic publications. Please take note of the Office of Management and Budget guidelines published March 27, 1987 (52 FR 10012) that include electronic publications and other nontraditional publishers as representatives of the news media.

This request is not being made for commercial purposes. All documents will be provided to the general public without charge.

In the event that there are fees, I am willing to pay up to $100. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

I look forward to your response within 20 working days, as the statute requires. If access to the records I am requesting will take longer, please contact me with information about when I might expect copies or the ability to inspect the requested records.

If you deny any or all of this request, please cite each specific exemption you feel justifies the refusal to release the information and notify me of the appeal procedures available to me under the law.

Sincerely,

Robert Skvarla, Jr.

title: Request for Incident at 25th Precinct on April 19th, 2023 Involving Officer Justin (Badge Number 9991) and Other Officers.

communications.subject: New York Freedom of Information Law Request: Request for Incident at 25th Precinct on April 19th, 2023 Involving Officer Justin (Badge Number 9991) and Other Officers.
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the New York Freedom of Information Law, I hereby request the following records:

Pertaining to an incident that occurred at the 25th precinct around 9:50 pm on April 19th, 2023, involving Officer Justin (badge number 9991) and any other officers involved in the incident.

Specifically, I am requesting all complaints filed against these officers for the past 2 years, as well as any depositions and complaint records related to this incident. I am particularly interested in any records related to any officer who claimed that recording in public is wrongful or any officer who accosted a member of the public for recording in public.

In addition, I am requesting any video recordings, including body camera footage and lobby footage, related to this incident. I request that you do not withhold or redact any records, and I would appreciate it if you could provide me with any case law that supports your decision to release these records.

Thank you for your attention to this matter. I look forward to receiving the requested records in a timely manner.

Sincerely,

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Jordan Lassiter

title: Records Related to Distribution of Military Equipment to Law Enforcement Agencies under the 1033 Program and Homeland Security Grant Program for the Past Five Years

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Records Related to Distribution of Military Equipment to Law Enforcement Agencies under the 1033 Program and Homeland Security Grant Program for the Past Five Years
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Related to the distribution of military equipment to law enforcement agencies under the 1033 Program, as well as any related information on the Homeland Security Grant Program, for the past five years. Specifically, I am requesting the following information:

Records of all requests made by law enforcement agencies for surplus military equipment, including the types of equipment requested and the justification for the request.
Records of all equipment distributed to law enforcement agencies under the 1033 Program and the Homeland Security Grant Program, including the types of equipment distributed, the quantity, and the receiving agencies.
Policies and procedures governing the distribution of surplus military equipment to law enforcement agencies, as well as any relevant guidance or training materials.
Records of any incidents involving the use of surplus military equipment by law enforcement agencies, including any investigations, disciplinary actions, or reports.
I request that any responsive records be provided to me without redactions or withholdings, except in cases where redactions or withholdings are required by law. Please note that the FOIA requires that any redactions or withholdings be limited to only the specific information that is exempt from disclosure under the FOIA, and that the agency must provide a justification for any such redactions or withholdings.

I also note that the FOIA requires agencies to provide the requested information in a timely manner. If the requested information is not provided within 20 business days, I reserve the right to pursue all legal remedies available to me.

To support my FOIA request, I would like to reference the case law of Judicial Watch, Inc. v. U.S. Dep’t of Justice, 365 F.3d 1108, 1113 (D.C. Cir. 2004), which holds that “governmental agencies bear the burden of showing that requested documents are exempt from disclosure under FOIA.” I would also like to reference the case law of Martin v. Dep’t of Justice, 488 F. Supp. 2d 443, 454 (D.D.C. 2007), which holds that “FOIA exemptions are to be narrowly construed, with any doubts resolved in favor of disclosure.”

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Jordan Lassiter

title: Mask Mandates

communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Delaware Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Emails, memos, letters, documents and other records discussing or mentioning implemented or proposed mask mandate policies, as well as discussions regarding their expiration or termination between January 1, 2020 and the present.

I am a member of the news media and request classification as such. I have previously written about the government and its activities, with some reaching over 100,000 readers in outlets such as Gizmodo, MuckRock, Motherboard, Property of the People, Unicorn Riot, and The Outline, among others. As such, as I have a reasonable expectation of publication and my editorial and writing skills are well established. In addition, I discuss and comment on the files online and make them available through non-profits such as the library Internet Archive and the journalist non-profit MuckRock, disseminating them to a large audience. While my research is not limited to this, a great deal of it, including this, focuses on the activities and attitudes of the government itself. As such, it is not necessary for me to demonstrate the relevance of this particular subject in advance.

As my primary purpose is to inform about government activities by reporting on it and making the raw data available, I request that fees be waived.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 15 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Jonathan Rudenberg, a citizen of Delaware, in coordination with Emma North-Best.

title: Records Related to Hydraulic Fracturing (Fracking) in New York State for the Past Five Years

communications.subject: New York Freedom of Information Law Request: Records Related to Hydraulic Fracturing (Fracking) in New York State for the Past Five Years
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the New York Freedom of Information Law, I hereby request the following records:

Related to hydraulic fracturing (fracking) activities in the state of New York over the past five years.

As a concerned citizen, I am interested in understanding the policies and practices that NY DEC employs to regulate and monitor fracking operations in the state. I am requesting any records in the possession of the NY DEC that pertain to the following:

Permits and applications for fracking operations submitted to the NY DEC, including but not limited to drilling permits and environmental impact assessments.
Records of inspections and enforcement actions taken by the NY DEC to ensure compliance with state regulations and environmental standards.
Records related to any spills, accidents, or other incidents related to fracking operations in the state of New York.
Records related to studies or research conducted by the NY DEC or other state agencies regarding the environmental impacts of fracking.
I request that you do not withhold or redact any responsive records, as I intend to pursue all available legal remedies, including filing a lawsuit to compel the production of records, if necessary.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Jordan Lassiter

title: US COAST GUARD ACADEMY - Applicant review

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: US COAST GUARD ACADEMY - Applicant review
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

The requested information should apply to the graduating class of 2027. 

1.	Coast Guard Academy Admission Partner Program requirements defined and recognized by the Coast Guard Academy Director of Admissions, Superintendent Instruction.
2.	Guidelines, standards, requirements for Appointments to Cadetship prescribed by the Secretary, including age limits, methods of selection of applicants, term of service as a cadet before graduation, and all other matters affecting such appointment.  All relevant standards required for appointment, admission, training, graduation, and commissioning.
3.	Applicants review process from submission to CEBB review process, recommendations to the Secretary for Appointment. 
4.	Process for errors in transcript by High School directly to USCGA admissions. 
5.	Appeals process for applicants. 
6.	Process for handling Candidate inquiries from State Representatives, and Congress member offering support of a candidate. 
7.	Pre-selection process for recruiting efforts, pre-selected candidates, target metrics. 
8.	Number of Applicants offered an appointment with a GPA of 3.7 or lower. 
9.	Number of Applicants offered an appointment with a PFE score of 200 or lower. 
10.	Number of Applicants offered an appointment without a Chemistry class on their High School transcript. 
11.	Number of Applicants offered an appointment without a Calculus class on their transcript. 
12.	Number of Applicants offered an appointment without Calculus and Chemistry on their High School Transcript. 
13.	Number of Applicants offered an appointment without 1 year or less of community service. 
14.	Number of Applicants offered an appointment who did not play Varsity Sports in High School. 
15.	Number of Applicants offered an appointment who played 2 years or less Varsity Sports. 
16.	Number of 1st time applicants offered an appointment for 2023. 
17.	Number of applicants offered an appointment for the USCGA Class of 2027 (existing seniors in high school). 
18.	Number of applicants offered an appointment who resided more than 200 miles away from Academy and DID NOT attend an ONSITE event at the Academy. 
19.	Number of applicants offered an appointment with 1 year or less of Leadership experience. 
20.	Number of applicants offered an appointment who are considered "HOOKS", have a tie to the Academy in some way. Family ties, parents' association, board, alumni, or tied to staff in some way. 
21.	Number of applicants offered an appointment with a household income of less than 60,000.00.
22.	Number of applicants offered an appointment with a family income greater than 100,000.00.
23.	USCGA definition of Inclusion and how it is applied during the application review and selection process. 
24.	Academy process to rectify any mistakes during the application review process. Checks and balances, forms, all related documentation used to catch errors, mistakes, omissions.
25.	Include any and all forms, documents used in the application review process. 
26. Number of applicants offered an appointment AFTER April 2nd.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Sally Jones

title: VA Overpass Accident

communications.subject: Virginia Freedom of Information Act Request: VA Overpass Accident
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Virginia Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

I am seeking any and all documents, reports, photographs, audio recordings, and video recordings pertaining to the incident, including but not limited to:

Police reports
Witness statements
Accident reports
911 call recordings
Body camera footage
Dashcam footage
Photos of the scene

The incident involved an individual who either jumped or fell off an overpass, hitting a car on the freeway below and killing the driver, Marisa Harris. The incident was investigated by the Virginia State Police.

To assist in identifying the records I am seeking, please note the following information:

Date of incident: October 28, 2017
Location of incident: Interstate 66 at Cedar Ln overpass
Victim's name: Marisa Harris

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically. When the records are ready, I will provide a link to a cloud-based service where the records may be easily uploaded.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days.

Sincerely,

Tom Nash, a citizen of Virginia, in coordination with Patrick Wells.

title: Access to Records request: index or indices containing the names and final dispositions for proceedings

communications.subject: New York Freedom of Information Law Request: Access to Records request: index or indices containing the names and final dispositions for proceedings
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to Section 1.23 of the rules and regulations of the Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor ("Access to records"), I hereby request the following:

To the extent practicable and on rolling basis if necessary, a copy of any electronic index or indices containing the names and final dispositions for Petitions, Applications for Licensure/Registration and Suspension/Revocation Proceedings.  The existence of such an index or indices is implied by charts in Annual Reports that tally cases by type and by disposition. 

To clarify, the request is for all records which are in electronic format (e.g., a database), regardless of original date the case. These records should be exported to a machine readable format (such as Comma Separated Value text file, or ".csv", or Excel spreadsheet, or ".xlsx"). They should not be printouts or scans. 

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter.

I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days.

Sincerely,

T. McElwee

communications.subject: RE: Wisconsin Open Records Act Request: Request for information on NovaTech (Wisconsin Department Of Financial Institutions)
communications.communication:
Pursuant to s. 551.607(2)(a), Stats., the department does not release or make available for public examination records and information obtained by the administrator in connection with a pending investigation/open case under s. 551.602.   Once the case is closed, the records are releasable as public records.

Because the department has denied all or a part of your records request, pursuant to s. 19.35(4)(b), Stats., I am required to inform you that this determination is subject to review by mandamus under s. 19.37(1) or upon application to the attorney general or a district attorney.

Sincerely,

Chris Green

Christopher N. Green
Assistant Chief Legal Counsel
Wisconsin Department of Financial Institutions
Email: Chris.Green1@dfi.wisconsin.gov<mailto:Chris.Green1@dfi.wisconsin.gov>
Cell: (608) 716-9687
Website: dfi.wi.gov<https://dfi.wi.gov/>

title: Drones and aircrafts

communications.subject: Washington Public Records Act Request: Drones and aircrafts
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Washington Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

This is a request under the Freedom of Information Act. I hereby request the following records:

Please provide all correspondence including memos, emails, and contracts between private companies/individuals/government departments/agencies, air traffic control via FAA FSDO in Bellevue, Nebraska, and state and local Omaha, Nebraska government and law enforcement relating to the permitted frequent and continuous daily and nightly flights of small and large civil, private, or military aircraft including drones over particular houses and neighborhoods in the Bellevue, Nebraska 37th St. location of the Sarpy area of Bellevue and Papillion Nebraska particularly over (therefore, referencing) the house and yard around 7813 S , 37th Street, from the time period 1 August 2022 upto the present date.

I also request that, if appropriate, fees be waived as I believe this request is in the public interest. The requested documents will be made available to the general public free of charge as part of the public information service at MuckRock.com, processed by a representative of the news media/press and is made in the process of news gathering and not for commercial usage.

In the event that fees cannot be waived, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Michael Williams

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Michael Keith Williams

Sincerely,

Michael Keith Williams

title: Request for Complaints Lodged Against Landlords in New York City

communications.subject: New York Freedom of Information Law Request: Request for Complaints Lodged Against Landlords in New York City
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the New York Freedom of Information Law, I hereby request the following records:

Complaints lodged against landlords in New York City from January 1st, 2019 to the present time, for all boroughs including the Bronx, Brooklyn, Manhattan, Queens, and Staten Island.

I am specifically requesting complaints that are not accessible on the NYC open data website. This includes any complaints that may be under review or pending investigation and have not yet been made public.

The requested documents should include, but not limited to, the following information:

Date of the complaint
Location of the property (including the borough and the street address)
Description of the alleged issue(s) reported in the complaint
Current status of the complaint (i.e., resolved, under review, pending investigation, etc.)
Type of action taken by the authorities, if any (i.e., citation, warning, fine, etc.)
Any follow-up actions taken by the authorities, if applicable (i.e., additional inspections, reprimands, etc.)
To protect the privacy of individuals involved, I request that any sensitive information regarding the complainant be redacted from the provided documents. However, I do not wish for any other information to be withheld, deleted, or redacted.

As you may know, the Freedom of Information Act provides the public with the right to access information held by government agencies. To support my request, I would like to cite several court cases that have recognized this right, including New York Times Co. v. United States, 403 U.S. 713 (1971), NLRB v. Robbins Tire & Rubber Co., 437 U.S. 214 (1978), and County of Suffolk v. Long Island Lighting Co., 710 N.Y.S.2d 846 (N.Y. App. Div. 2000).

I would appreciate it if you could provide me with the requested information in a digital format, such as a CSV or Excel spreadsheet, sent via email or a secure file sharing platform.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Jordan Lassiter

title: FBI for Documents Related to Hal Turner's Activities and Associations

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: FBI for Documents Related to Hal Turner's Activities and Associations
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Records pertaining to Hal Turner. Specifically, I am requesting any documents related to Mr. Turner's activities, communications, or associations that were collected, created, or maintained by the FBI.

To provide context, Hal Turner is a political commentator and radio host who has been involved in controversial and potentially illegal activities, including making threatening and harassing statements directed at public officials and journalists. He has also been linked to extremist and white supremacist groups.

In making this request, I cite the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA), 5 U.S.C. § 552, and request a prompt response to this request, as required by 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(6)(A)(i).

In support of this request, I would like to cite the following case law:

Electronic Frontier Foundation v. Department of Justice, 739 F.3d 1 (D.C. Cir. 2014): This case established that the FBI's Electronic Surveillance (ELSUR) indices are subject to FOIA disclosure, and that requesters may seek a full integrity search of these indices using specific key strings related to the subject of the request.

Please conduct a full search of all FBI records systems, including ELSUR indices, for any records related to Hal Turner that fall within the scope of this request. Specifically, I request records related to:

Communications, meetings, or other interactions between Mr. Turner and FBI personnel or informants.
Any investigations or surveillance activities related to Mr. Turner's activities, communications, or associations.
Any records related to extremist or white supremacist groups with which Mr. Turner has been associated.
To facilitate the search, I request that the following key string be used: "Hal Turner."

I also remind you that any responsive records must be provided in their entirety and without redaction, unless a specific FOIA exemption applies. If any records are withheld, redacted, or deleted, I request a written explanation for the withholding that cites the specific FOIA exemption(s) relied upon.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Jordan Lassiter

title: Records Related to Password Policies and Procedures

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Records Related to Password Policies and Procedures
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Pertaining to the NSA's policies and procedures for the handling of passwords. Specifically, I am requesting any documentation related to the following:

Any policies ,procedures or memos related to the creation, management, or use of passwords by NSA personnel or contractors.
Any training materials or guidelines provided to NSA personnel or contractors regarding password security.
Any records of security breaches or incidents related to the compromise of passwords within the NSA's systems or networks.
Any reports or studies related to the effectiveness of the NSA's password policies and procedures.
I am making this request under the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA), 5 U.S.C. § 552. Pursuant to 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(6)(A)(i), I request a prompt response to this request.

In support of this request, I would like to cite the following case law:

Milner v. Department of the Navy, 562 U.S. 562 (2011): This case established that FOIA's exemptions must be narrowly construed, and that any doubt about the applicability of an exemption should be resolved in favor of disclosure.
Phillippi v. CIA, 546 F.2d 1009 (D.C. Cir. 1976): This case established the "Glomar response," which allows an agency to refuse to confirm or deny the existence of records in certain limited circumstances, such as where disclosure would compromise national security or reveal classified information.

Please note that if the NSA issues a Glomar response to this request, I reserve the right to challenge the response and seek judicial review. Additionally, I request that if any responsive records are withheld, redacted, or deleted, the NSA provide a written justification for the withholding that cites the specific FOIA exemption(s) relied upon.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Jordan Lassiter

title: FOIA DHS-EOIR re IJ Riggs (CLT) Credibility Determinations, Correspondence, and BIA Reversals/Remands

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: FOIA DHS-EOIR re IJ Riggs (CLT) Credibility Determinations, Correspondence, and BIA Reversals/Remands
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

1) The decisions issued by the Board of Immigration Appeals between October 1, 2016, and the date of processing of this request, arising from cases decided by former-IJ George W. Riggs, that were administratively closed, reversed, background check remand, and/or remand.

2)  I would request any printouts, summaries, spreadsheets, reports, or other records or datasets that may encompass or address how many of removal orders included a negative credibility determination for any Respondent(s) for whom former-IJ George W. Riggs issued removal orders in protection/form I-589 cases (in other words, decisions on Asylum, Wittholding of Removal, or Relief under the Convention Against Torture), after merits/individual hearings occurred, between October 1, 2016 and the end of his tenure at EOIR.

3) All correspondence or communications in any medium (including but not limited to any email, fax, letter, text/SMS/MMS, memorandum, voicemail, audio recording, sticky-note, or any attachment thereto, and any conversion of any of the foregoing from a digital to analog form/format, or vice-versa) to or from former-IJ George W. Riggs, from October 1, 2016 through the end of his tenure at EOIR, containing the words "credibility," "credible," "incredible," "incoherent," "demeanor," "candor," "evasive," "non-responsive," "responsiveness," "inconsistent," "consistent," "consistency," "facial expression(s)," "body language," "standard language," or "addendum of law," or any abbreviation, contraction, misspelling, pluralization, or paraphrase thereof.

4) Copies of each and every "standard language addendum of law" or any substantially similar 'boilerplate' or 'template' document utilized by former-IJ George W. Riggs as an exhibit in, as an attachment to, or as a drafting aid for any merits decision in a protection/form I-589 matter.

The requested records will be made available to the general public via a FOIA records clearinghouse, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes; rather, the results will be disseminated to interested individuals free of charge, and with no pecuniary gain to the Requestor, who is not (I hope and assume) the subject of any of these records.  Thus, we would request that fees be waived.

Please search all records regarding agency business.  You may not exclude searches of files or emails in the personal custody of your officials, such as personal email accounts.  Records of official business conducted using unofficial systems or stored outside of official files is subject to the Federal Records Act and FOIA.  It is not adequate to rely on policies and procedures that require officials to move such information to official systems within a certain period of time; I exercise and specifically preserve and assert my right to records contained in those files even if material has not yet been moved to official systems or if officials have, through negligence or willfulness, failed to meet their obligations. 

If it is your position that any portion of the requested records is exempt from disclosure, I request that you provide an index of those documents as required under Vaughn v. Rosen, describe each document claimed as exempt with sufficient specificity to determine whether it should be exempt under FOIA, and discuss the consequences of disclosing, specifically identifying the reasons why a particular exemption is relevant and correlating those claims with the particular part of a withheld document to which they apply.

If it is your position that a record contains non-exempt segments, but that those non-exempt segments are so dispersed throughout the document as to make segregation impossible, please state what portion of the document is non-exempt, and how the material is dispersed throughout the document. If a request is denied in whole, please state specifically that it is not reasonable to segregate portions of the record for release.

You should institute a preservation hold on information responsive to this request. I intend to pursue all legal avenues to enforce my right of access under the FOIA, including litigation if that becomes necessary. Accordingly, the EOIR is on notice that litigation is reasonably foreseeable.

If it will accelerate release of responsive records to me, please also provide responsive material on a rolling basis.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Derrick Hensley

communications.subject: RE: [EXTERNAL] Freedom of Information Act Request: FOIA DHS-EOIR re IJ Riggs (CLT) Credibility Determinations, Correspondence, and BIA Reversals/Remands
communications.communication:
Dear Requester:

Thank you for contacting the Executive Office for Immigration Review. Please read this email in its entirety for important information about upcoming improvements to the EOIR Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) and Privacy Act (PA) request process.

As of December 1, 2022, EOIR no longer accepts FOIA or PA requests by email. EOIR strongly encourages individuals to submit FOIA and PA requests through EOIR's Public Access Link (PAL)<https://foia.eoir.justice.gov/app/Home.aspx>. We will continue to monitor this inbox for correspondence other than initial FOIA requests.

PAL offers several benefits for individuals submitting a FOIA or PA request to EOIR:

  *   Nearly instant submission of requests;
  *   Ability to track status of requests;
  *   Ability to browse the FOIA Reading Room;
  *   Payment of required fees online;
  *   Response to requests immediately upon processing;
  *   Receive email alerts as soon as requested records are ready; and
  *   Downloadable records at any time after processing.
To submit your FOIA or PA request, visit PAL<https://foia.eoir.justice.gov/app/Home.aspx> to register for an account.

PAL provides accelerated processing and delivery of EOIR’s response to your FOIA requests, but we understand it may not be right for everyone. If you prefer, you may still send your requests via postal mail. The mailing address for the EOIR FOIA Service Center is available at https://foia.eoir.justice.gov/app/Home.aspx.

As a reminder, the Request a ROP<https://www.justice.gov/eoir/ROPrequest> process is available to those requesting a Record of Proceeding (ROP) for a case before an immigration court or the Board of Immigration Appeals (BIA). The Request a ROP process allows an individual who is the subject of a ROP, or someone with a specific legal relationship with that person, to submit a ROP request directly to the applicable immigration court or the BIA, rather than to the FOIA team. Requesters may use the Request a ROP process in lieu of or in addition to the FOIA request process. However, please note that requesting a ROP through both processes may result in significantly delayed delivery. For more information, see the ROP Request Instructions<https://www.justice.gov/eoir/ROPrequest>.

Please be advised that if you have multiple accounts, which could be connected to PAL requests or e-mail/mail requests, we will no longer merge the accounts together. Therefore, it is to your advantage to use your currently existing PAL account (or create a PAL account if you do not have one) and only submit requests under that PAL account moving forward.

We look forward to offering you faster processing times with PAL, although due to the large number of requests we receive, there may still be a slight delay in processing your request. We apologize for this inconvenience and appreciate your understanding and patience.

We will continue to monitor this email for communications regarding existing requests.

Sincerely,

FOIA Service Center
Office of the General Counsel
Executive Office for Immigration Review
Public Access Link (PAL)<https://foia.eoir.justice.gov/app/Home.aspx>

communications.subject: Request Acknowledgement by DOJ-EOIR PAL
communications.communication:
Dear Derrick Hensley, 

This response acknowledges receipt of your Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request by the Executive Office for Immigration Review (EOIR).  Your request has been assigned control number 2023-49093. 

Please be advised that the status of requests submitted through the Public Access Link (PAL) may be tracked at https://foia.eoir.justice.gov/app/Home.aspx, and you will receive an email response to your request upon completion of processing. The status of requests submitted by email or mail may not be trackable through the PAL, but you will still receive an email or mailed response to your request upon completion of processing. (https://foia.eoir.justice.gov/app/Home.aspx) Please ensure the email address you provided in PAL will be able to receive the messages we send you. Messages rejected by your email account will not be rerouted to you. 
Please be aware that EOIR is a component of the Department of Justice and the custodian of records for the “Record of Proceedings” (ROP), which is the compilation of documents and digital audio recordings produced in proceedings before the immigration courts and the BIA. The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) is the custodian of records for the “A-file,” which is a series of records of a person’s immigration history and is maintained and stored by DHS. EOIR is not the custodian of records for DHS or its components, nor does EOIR have access to DHS’s A-files. EOIR does not create an ROP until matters are initiated by DHS. Nevertheless, EOIR may create and maintain ROPs for proceedings other than removal proceedings (i.e., credible fear reviews, bond hearings). You may request a copy of your Notice to Appear (NTA) and full A-file from DHS. (https://www.dhs.gov/foia) 
Note that parties to immigration cases (including respondents and their representatives of record) have the option to request their Record of Proceedings directly from the immigration court or Board of Immigration Appeals. Please see the instructions here: https://www.justice.gov/eoir/ROPrequest. (https://www.justice.gov/eoir/ROPrequest) 

Please be advised that due to necessary operational changes as a result of the national emergency concerning the novel coronavirus disease (COVID-19) outbreak, there may be significant delay in the processing of your request. 

If you have filed a fee waiver request, EOIR will address the fee waiver in a separate letter. Most requests for records of proceedings do not require any fees; however, if the fees for processing the request are estimated to exceed $25.00, EOIR will notify you before processing the request to determine whether you will commit to paying the fee or whether you wish to narrow the scope of your request to reduce the fee. Fees may be charged for searching records at the rate of $4.75 (administrative)/$10.00 (professional) per quarter hour, and for duplication of copies at the rate of $.05 per copy. The first 100 copies and two hours of search time are not charged, and charges must exceed $25.00 before we will charge a fee. 

The FOIA requires an agency to respond within 20 working days after receipt of the request, and EOIR endeavors to meet this standard.  The FOIA permits a ten-day extension of this time period, pursuant to 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(6)(B), based on unusual circumstances.  Your request involves “unusual circumstances,” and EOIR is extending the time period to respond by an additional 10 working days because your request requires the collection of records from field offices, or involves a search, collection, and review of voluminous records, or requires consultation with another agency or two or more agency components. 

EOIR FOIA requests are placed in one of three tracks. Track one is for those requests that seek and receive expedited processing pursuant to subsection (a)(6)(E) of the FOIA. Track two is for simple requests that do not involve voluminous records or lengthy consultations with other entities.  Track three is for complex requests that involve voluminous records and for which lengthy or numerous consultations are required, or those requests that may involve sensitive records.  As a matter of default, your request has been placed in track two for simple requests.  If you have requested expedited processing, EOIR will contact you in a separate letter. 

If you have any questions regarding unusual circumstances, you may contact the EOIR FOIA Service Center or FOIA Public Liaison at (703) 605-1297 or EOIR.FOIArequests@usdoj.gov to discuss reformulation or an alternative time frame to process your request, or for any further assistance regarding any aspect of your request. Alternatively, you may contact the Office of Government Information Services (OGIS) at the National Archives and Records Administration to inquire about the FOIA mediation services they offer.  The contact information for OGIS is as follows: Office of Government Information Services, National Archives and Records Administration, Room 2510, 8601 Adelphi Road, College Park, Maryland 20740-6001; e-mail at ogis@nara.gov; telephone at (202) 741-5770; toll free at (877) 684-6448; or facsimile at (202) 741-5769. 
 
Sincerely, 

FOIA Intake

communications.subject: DOJ-EOIR FOIA Request # 2023-49093

If you plan to re-submit a request for this individual, please use the Public Access Link (PAL). As of December 1, 2022, the EOIR FOIA Service Center no longer accepts FOIA requests by email. (https://foia.eoir.justice.gov/app/Home.aspx) Such evidence may include a completed Form EOIR-59 or (https://www.justice.gov/eoir/page/file/1380121/download) DOJ-361 (https://www.justice.gov/ust/file/doj361_form.pdf/download) signed and dated byyour client (or you, if you are requesting your own records). Alternatively, if you are requesting your own records, you may provide your full name, currentaddress, date and place of birth, and either (1) have your signature witnessed by a notary, or (2) include the following statementimmediately above your signature : “I declare under penalty of perjurythat the foregoing is true and correct. Executed on [date].” If you are a parent or guardian requesting documents for a child, in addition to the above evidence, you must also submit proof ofparentage (e.g., birth certificate) or guardianship (e.g., court order), as well as verification of your ownidentity. Verification of your identity must include your full name, current address, date and place ofbirth, and either (1) your signature witnessed by a notary, or (2) the following statement immediately above your signature: “I declare underpenalty of perjury that the foregoing is true and correct. Executed on [date].” For more information on providing proper documentation for your FOIA request, please visit Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) (justice.gov). (https://www.justice.gov/eoir/freedom-information-act-foia) 
Please be aware that EOIR is a component of the Department of Justice and the custodian of records for the “Record of Proceedings” (ROP), which is the compilation of documents and digital audio recordings produced in proceedings before the immigration courts and the BIA. The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) is the custodian of records for the “A-file,” which is a series of records of a person’s immigration history and is maintained and stored by DHS. EOIR is not the custodian of records for DHS or its components, nor does EOIR have access to DHS’s A-files . EOIR does not create an ROP until matters are initiated by DHS. Nevertheless, EOIR may create and maintain ROPs for proceedings other than removal proceedings (i.e., credible fear reviews, bond hearings). You may request a copy of your Notice to Appear (NTA) and full A-file from DHS (https://www.dhs.gov/foia) Note that parties to immigration cases(including respondents and their representatives of record) have the option torequest their Record of Proceedings directly from the immigration court orBoard of Immigration Appeals. Please see the instructions here: https://www.justice.gov/eoir/ROPrequest. (https://www.justice.gov/eoir/ROPrequest) 
You may contact the FOIA Public Liaison at (703) 605-1297 orEOIR.FOIArequests@usdoj.gov for any further assistance and to discuss anyaspect of your request. Alternatively, you may contact the Office of GovernmentInformation Services (OGIS) at the National Archives and Records Administrationto inquire about the FOIA mediation services they offer. The contactinformation for OGIS is as follows: Office of Government Information Services,National Archives and Records Administration, Room 2510, 8601 Adelphi Road,College Park, Maryland 20740-6001; e-mail at ogis@nara.gov; telephone at (202)741-5770; toll free at (877) 684-6448; or facsimile at (202) 741-5769. 

If you are not satisfied with the Executive Office for Immigration Review’sdetermination in response to this request, you may administratively appeal bywriting to the Director, Office of Information Policy (OIP), United StatesDepartment of Justice, 441 G Street, NW, 6th Floor, Washington, D.C. 20530, oryou may submit an appeal through OIP’s FOIA STAR portal by creating an accountfollowing the instructions on OIP’s website https://www.justice.gov/oip/submit-and-track-request-or-appeal (https://www.justice.gov/oip/submit-and-track-request-or-appeal) . Your appeal must be postmarkedor electronically transmitted within 90 days of the date of my response to yourrequest. If you submit your appeal by mail, both the letter and the envelopeshould be clearly marked “Freedom of Information Act Appeal.” Sincerely, FOIA Intake

title: Request for NSA Employee Calendar Events for 2023 and Related Policies and Procedures

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Request for NSA Employee Calendar Events for 2023 and Related Policies and Procedures
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Related to the calendar events of NSA employees for the year 2023.

Specifically, I am requesting any and all records related to the following calendar events for NSA employees for the year 2023:

Training sessions, workshops, and other professional development opportunities.
Meetings and appointments with external organizations, including government agencies, contractors, and private sector entities.
Speaking engagements and conference presentations.
Travel schedules, including dates, locations, and purposes of travel.
Other events or activities that are included on the calendars of NSA employees.
I would also like to request any policies or procedures governing the maintenance and use of employee calendars at the NSA.

I understand that certain records may be exempt from disclosure under FOIA. However, I request that you do not use the Glomar response to neither confirm nor deny the existence of responsive records, as this would not comply with the requirements of FOIA.

Furthermore, I would like to cite several relevant court cases in support of my FOIA request, including "American Civil Liberties Union v. Department of Defense," "Judicial Watch, Inc. v. National Archives and Records Administration," and "Department of Justice v. Reporters Committee for Freedom of the Press." These cases have upheld the public's right to access government records, including calendar events of government employees, under FOIA.

I request that you do not withhold or redact any responsive records, as I intend to pursue all available legal remedies, including filing a lawsuit to compel the production of records, if necessary.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Jordan Lassiter

title: Records Related to NSA Policies and Procedures for Handling FOIA Requests, Including the Use of the Glomar Response

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Records Related to NSA Policies and Procedures for Handling FOIA Requests, Including the Use of the Glomar Response
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Related to the NSA's policies and procedures for handling FOIA requests, including the use of the Glomar response to neither confirm nor deny the existence of responsive records.

In particular, I am requesting any and all documents, including but not limited to manuals, training materials, and internal memos, related to the following:

The NSA's policies and procedures for determining whether to release or withhold information in response to FOIA requests.
The criteria used by the NSA to determine when to use the Glomar response to neither confirm nor deny the existence of responsive records.
The NSA's policies and procedures for responding to requests for expedited processing of FOIA requests.
The NSA's policies and procedures for processing complex or voluminous FOIA requests.
The NSA's policies and procedures for responding to FOIA appeals and litigation.
I am also requesting any records related to the NSA's training of FOIA officers and staff on the proper handling of FOIA requests, including the use of the Glomar response.

Furthermore, I would like to cite several relevant court cases in support of my FOIA request, including "American Civil Liberties Union v. Department of Defense," "Electronic Frontier Foundation v. NSA," and "National Security Archive v. CIA." These cases have addressed the importance of transparency and accountability in the FOIA process and the need for agencies to provide detailed explanations for their actions in closing or denying FOIA requests.

I request that you do not withhold or redact any responsive records, as I intend to pursue all available legal remedies, including filing a lawsuit to compel the production of records, if necessary.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Jordan Lassiter

title: Records Related to Hydraulic Fracturing and its Impact on Wildlife and Habitat in Washington State

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Records Related to Hydraulic Fracturing and its Impact on Wildlife and Habitat in Washington State
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Held by the Washington Department of Fish and Wildlife (WDFW) related to hydraulic fracturing, or "fracking," in Washington State for the past five years.

As a concerned citizen, I am interested in understanding the WDFW's policies and practices with respect to the management and conservation of wildlife and habitat impacted by fracking activities. I am requesting any records in the possession of the WDFW that pertain to the following:

Communications and correspondence between the WDFW and other state or federal agencies, as well as industry stakeholders, regarding the impact of fracking on wildlife and habitat in Washington State.
Records related to the permitting process for fracking activities in Washington State, including but not limited to applications, authorizations, and reports.
Records related to monitoring and enforcement activities conducted by the WDFW to ensure compliance with environmental regulations related to fracking.
Records related to the impact of fracking on wildlife and habitat, including but not limited to studies, surveys, and reports.

I request that you do not withhold or redact any responsive records, as I intend to pursue all available legal remedies, including filing a lawsuit to compel the production of records, if necessary.

title: Records Related to Gray Wolf Management and Conservation in New York State

communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the New York Freedom of Information Law, I hereby request the following records:

Held by the New York Department of Environmental Conservation (NYDEC) related to the management and conservation of the gray wolf population in New York State.

As a concerned citizen, I am interested in understanding the policies and practices that NYDEC employs to manage and protect the gray wolf population. I am requesting any records in the possession of the NYDEC that pertain to the following:

title: McCurtain County Sheriffs Department (OK) Social Media

communications.subject: Oklahoma Open Records Act Request: McCurtain County Sheriffs Department (OK) Social Media
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Oklahoma Open Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

This is part of a survey of how government agencies use social media accounts.

This request seeks records relating to the Facebook located at https://www.facebook.com/profile.php?id=100076363850310. An example of what each of these records look like is attached and available at https://bit.ly/facebookfoia.

In order to access the requested information, you will first need to take the following steps:

1. Log into the page account or a Facebook account with managerial access to the Facebook page. For information on this type of access, see: https://www.facebook.com/help/187316341316631.)
2. "Switch" to the page account. To do so, click your profile photo in the top right, then click "See all profiles", then select the Page you want to switch into. (See the instructions here: https://www.facebook.com/help/123930246348340).
3. Click "Professional dashboard" on the left

I request the following information:

1. The "Page and Tagging" information. Once logged into the account, go to this URL: https://www.facebook.com/settings/?tab=timeline&privacy_source=timeline_gear_menu.

2. The list of blocked users. This information is accessible by following these steps:
(a) Once logged into the account, go to this URL: https://www.facebook.com/settings?tab=blocking
(b) Click "Edit" next to "Block users"
(c) Click "See your blocked list"

3. The list of blocked Pages. This information is accessible by following these steps:
(a) Once logged into the account, go to this URL: https://www.facebook.com/settings?tab=blocking
(b) Click "Edit" next to "Block Pages"
(c) Click "See your blocked list"

4. The list of "Moderation Assist" criteria. Once logged into the account, go to the "Professional Dashboard" and then click "Moderation Assist" on the left side of the screen.


5. If the "Moderation Assist" criteria includes "Comment has certain keywords", the list of keywords. This information is accessible by following the steps in (4) above, then:
(a) Click the pencil (edit) icon next to each of the criteria ("Comment has certain keywords").
(b) Click "Edit" from the drop-down menu.
(c) Click "Comment has certain keywords"
(d) On the right side of the "Keywords" menu, click the ellipsis menu ("...")
(e) Click "Copy list" from the dropdown menu.
(f) Provide the information from the list.

6. If the "Moderation Assist" criteria includes "Comment has specific links", the list of keywords. This information is accessible by following the steps in (4) above, then:
(a) Click the pencil (edit) icon next to each of the criteria ("Comment has specific links").
(b) Click "Edit" from the drop-down menu.
(c) Click "Comment has links to specific sites."
(d) Provide the information from the "Added sites" list.

7. The list of people with Facebook access. From the "Professional dashboard" page, click "Page Access" on the left side of the screen. Alternatively, visit this URL: https://www.facebook.com/settings/?tab=profile_access.

8. The list of moderation actions in the Activity log. This information is accessible by following these steps:
(a) Once logged into the account, go to the "Professional Dashboard."
(b) Click "Moderation Assist" on the left side of the screen 
(c) Click "Activity log" on the left side of the screen 
(c) From the dropdown menu labeled "Visible comments", select "Hidden comments".
(d) Continue scrolling down until the complete list is loaded.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days.

Sincerely,

Adam Steinbaugh

title: Gray Wolf Management and Conservation in Washington State

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Gray Wolf Management and Conservation in Washington State
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Held by the Washington Department of Fish and Wildlife (WDFW) related to the management and conservation of the gray wolf population in Washington State.

As a concerned citizen, I am interested in understanding the policies and practices that WDFW employs to manage and protect the gray wolf population. I am requesting any records in the possession of the WDFW that pertain to the following:

Wolf population management plans, reports, and studies.
Records of communication between the WDFW and other state or federal agencies, as well as tribal governments and non-governmental organizations, regarding gray wolf management and conservation.
Records related to permits issued by the WDFW for the lethal removal of wolves, including but not limited to applications, authorizations, and reports.
Records related to monitoring and research activities conducted by the WDFW, including but not limited to GPS tracking data and population surveys.
I request that you do not withhold or redact any responsive records, as I intend to pursue all available legal remedies, including filing a lawsuit to compel the production of records, if necessary.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Jordan Lassiter

title: Complaints and Correspondence Regarding Dave Chappelle

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Complaints and Correspondence Regarding Dave Chappelle
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Relating to any complaints or correspondence received by the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) about the comedian Dave Chappelle.

In recent years, Dave Chappelle's comedy has sparked controversy and debate over his use of humor that some consider to be insensitive or offensive. Some of his jokes have been criticized for perpetuating harmful stereotypes and contributing to a culture of discrimination against marginalized communities. In particular, his comments about the transgender community in his Netflix special "The Closer" have drawn widespread criticism and calls for the streaming service to remove the program.

Given the public interest in this matter, I am requesting any records in the possession of the FCC related to complaints or correspondence received about Dave Chappelle, as well as any records of communication between Mr. Chappelle, his representatives, or his management and the FCC. This includes but is not limited to letters, emails, memos, and any other forms of communication.

I request that you do not withhold or redact any responsive records, as I intend to pursue all available legal remedies, including filing a lawsuit to compel the production of records, if necessary.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Jordan Lassiter
